Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.5.Ua.4 - Eastern Pacific Mangrove EN (VU -- EN)'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.5.Ua.4 - Eastern Pacific Mangrove EN (VU -- EN)'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.5.Ua.4 - Eastern Pacific Mangrove' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.5.Ua Atlantic & Caribbean & East Pacific Mangrove' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Classification-system.Classification-element: 1.7 Forest - Subtropical/Tropical Mangrove Vegetation Above High Tide Level

Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre de Chiapas moist forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Costa Rican seasonal moist forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sonoran-Sinaloan transition subtropical dry forest'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra de la Laguna dry forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Gulf of California xeric scrub'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.5.Ua.4 - Eastern Pacific Mangrove' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for EN was reached for criterion. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os VU -- EN.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of recent change in woodland cover reached the threshold for VU for subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of NT -- EN.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A2b. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A2b could be in the range of VU -- LC.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of historical change in woodland cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of VU -- EN.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Assessment-unit.name: Peru

Ecosystem-subset.name: National: Peru
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Country-level assessment of '1.A.5.Ua.4 - Eastern Pacific Mangrove' macrogroup in Peru.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for VU was reached for criterion.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: This subcriterion was evaluated, but the uncertainty in the estimates of recent changes in woodland cover was too high to reliable assign a category.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was near to the threshold for Vulnerable. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened under subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: This subcriterion was evaluated, but the uncertainty in the estimates of historical changes in woodland cover was too high to reliable assign a category.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.5.Ua.5 - Western Atlantic & Caribbean Mangrove NT'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.5.Ua.5 - Western Atlantic & Caribbean Mangrove NT'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.5.Ua.5 - Western Atlantic & Caribbean Mangrove' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.5.Ua Atlantic & Caribbean & East Pacific Mangrove' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Classification-system.Classification-element: 1.7 Forest - Subtropical/Tropical Mangrove Vegetation Above High Tide Level

Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Serra do Mar coastal forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Cordillera La Costa montane forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Araya and Paria xeric scrub'
WWF ecoregion 'Central American Atlantic moist forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Trinidad and Tobago moist forests'
Global 200 ecoregion 'Amazon River and Flooded Forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.5.Ua.5 - Western Atlantic & Caribbean Mangrove' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: None of the evaluated indicators reached the thresholds for Vulnerable for any criteria, but it almost reached the threshold for criterion and could become Vulnerable soon. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: None of the evaluated indicators reached the thresholds for Vulnerable for any criteria, but it almost reached the threshold for criteria and could become Vulnerable soon. Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was near to the threshold for Vulnerable. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened under subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of LC -- VU.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Country-level assessment of '1.A.5.Ua.5 - Western Atlantic & Caribbean Mangrove' macrogroup in Cuba.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for VU was reached for criteria. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os NT -- EN.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of recent change in woodland cover reached the threshold for VU for subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of LC -- EN.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of historical change in woodland cover reached the threshold for VU for subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of NT -- EN.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Assessment-unit.name: Cayman Islands

Ecosystem-subset.name: National: Cayman Islands
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Country-level assessment of '1.A.5.Ua.5 - Western Atlantic & Caribbean Mangrove' macrogroup in Cayman Islands.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for VU was reached for criterion.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: This subcriterion was evaluated, but the uncertainty in the estimates of recent changes in woodland cover was too high to reliable assign a category.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was near to the threshold for Vulnerable. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened under subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: This subcriterion was evaluated, but the uncertainty in the estimates of historical changes in woodland cover was too high to reliable assign a category.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.
